They kindly suggest us to park close to them (not asking any money). No amenities except a trash basket. Maybe water inside the cemetery, but didn't search for it.

name: Parque Urbano
description: Nice park with a lot of shade.Fresh air. We slept here with other big rig overlander. If you walk a lit bit, you will find a shower at the restaurant.

name: Local Market
description:
Local Market with Nicaragua typical food
Try: Gallo Pinto, Vigorón, Nacatamal (Friday, saturday), Baho

Good price for fruit and vegetable!

name: Charming Backpackers Casita
description: Perfect stop for the tired traveller. We are located !5 min from Nagarote down a country road. With views of Momotombo and surrounding hills its the perfect stop to rest and recharge. Our Casita is furnished with a double bed, mini fridge, hot plate toaster oven, fans and wash room with cold shower. We have good wifi and cellular reception. $28 US dollars per night.

name: Police “Checkpoint” - Attempted Bribery
description:
We were asked to pull over for a police checkpoint. They asked for our license and title for our car. They claimed that our lights were illegal (we have a few extra lights mounted on our truck). They said we were going to have to pay a fine and they threatened to keep my driver's license. We knew they were trying to get us to pay a bribe so we just said, “That’s fine. Take the license and give us the ticket”. They kept repeating their threat to keep the license. They even said “Aren’t you too busy to deal with this? When do you leave Nicaragua?” but we just kept saying “That’s fine. We have many weeks in the country. You can give us a ticket”. Eventually, after about 5 minutes of this back and forth, they gave us back the license and let us leave. 

Do not pay any bribes to these crooked cops!! They are bluffing!

name: AM/PM - Sells Garrafones
description: We were able to buy a 20L Garrafon to fill our tank and return the empty bottle to them without paying deposit. It was $123 Cord. Expensive water but it has been hard to find purifcadoras in Nicaragua. Probably you could do this at many of the AM/PM convince stores. Took some explaining in Spanish to get them to understand what we were after.

name: bad road!!!
description: This road to the Cerro Negro cost us a lot of time, caused a lot of dents and scratches.  The road conditions are bad and narrow.  Many overhanging trees, hardly possible for tall cars.  We would recommend the route from the direction of Leon.

name: Police control
description: police control. Vehicle papers and insurance were required.  Short discussion about the driver's license being a copy.  After that we were passed on in a friendly manner

name: Fenced parking lot
description: Small and chargeable parking lot behind the hotel austria. Safe and good for visiting the city.

name: Veredas de Veracruz, #A3
description:
I live in a safe and private residential.
I can give you drinking water.
I can allow you to sleep in front of my house.
I can let you park in my backyard.
It is a safe place, I have security cameras.
There is an access needle.
Ask for Paulo McNally or Eyling Montenegro.

name: Drinking Water - Puma station
description: Drinking water on the side of gas station. Just ask for the key (llave) and you have access to potable water.

name: Water non potable
description: Non drinking water with spigot. Accessible for any size rig. 5 meter hose will do it. Didn’t need to get gas to have access

name: AJ Fernandez Cigar factory
description:
Amazing tour through the cigar factory. Lasts for about an hour and is super interesting. Ask at the reception for Mario. He speaks perfect english

20$/person

You get two cigars each to take home

name: La Cueva de el Grifo Loco
description:
After a certain hassle to find a place around this surfer's paradise, Miramar, I found Adriano, a gentle Italian host that has travelled the world on 2 wheels, which is more than willing to offer cost x benefit for travelers. Everything is new, full facilities, very safe and fenced.

I stayed in a dorm for $12 however I asked him about camping, and he said 8$ for up to two people in a van and $5 in your hammock or tent. He also has cabañas for up to 4 people for $35. 

It is also a nice and high area, so it is always fresh at the hostel. 5 minutes walk from the surf, and you can get a boat at La Sirena lodge for $20 to surf Sandino.

name: Beach
description:
slept here 2 nights, no problems, no noise except the sound of the waves from the lake, a bit trashy
very nice sunrise behind the volcano

name: Vulcano Ecovista
description: Hotel and Restaurant with the posibility to stay with the RV in the grassy parking lot with some shade. Price February 2024: 10 USD per person. Clean pool, toilets and cold outdoor shower. Some awesome terraces with a magnificent view on the nearby volcano Masaya (especially at sunset time).

name: Robberies in Popoyo region
description:
Unfortunately we had our belongins stolen at this beach. We were warned about how dangerous this whole region is, so at least we were lucky to leave our phones in the camping. We have a trained dog that was apparently attacked when he possibly tried to defend our things under the tree as he had little blood on him. We were surfing and it is our second day in the area.

While camping at Luna, where we are, two overlanders had both their land cruiser windows broken while parked and had phone and belongins robbed too two days ago.

Another overlander staying long term here said to NOT walk with your phone at night in the streets as robbery is active. I also noticed that most buildings have security 24/7, which just proves the sketch around this area.

DO NOT leave your things on the beach and CAUTION leaving vehicles unattended at wild camping or streets, go to a parking or camping for Nicarágua. Even a dog leash was stolen 4 days ago which was out of the van by Masaya.

name: Secluded Beach
description:
Motorcycles and bicycles only. 

Secluded beach used by locals to hunt for crabs, and a few cows come to the lake betweenthe beach and the road for a drink. The odd surfer comes here,  too. But we mostly had it to ourselves.

Motorcycles and bicycles only. You basically ride the footpath down to the beach. There is also a spot half way where locals park their little bikes. I suggest walk it before you ride it to see what you're in for. Easy when dry, could be slippery when muddy/wet.

Small opening at edge of fence that looks like a footpath into the bushes. Keep your eyes peeled. 

It's idyllic once you're down there. Pitched our tent above the high tide line. bushes for shade and perfect for hammock. 

Best to walk all the way to the left of the beach for a swim where the little bay is (best at medium tide). Everywhere else has rocks and there are spiky sea urchins and rock fish you don't want to step on...

Tiny bit of Tigo reception. Village with small tienda and fresh fish 3km away for supplies.

We stayed two magical nights. Locals were ok with us being here and left us to it.

name: ATM
description:
ATM next to the main road. 
IG: MoraVentures

name: La Virgen on the beach
description:
Nice spot directly on the beach. Hard sand.
We asked the restaurant at the entrance and they said OK.
Windy - good place for kitesurfing.
We stayed 2 nights without any problem.
You can rent palapas to have a place under the shadow.
Lots of Nica during the weekend and the beach was very dirty after ...

name: Hotel Real de Leon
description: Great place. USD 116 for 2 adults and 2 children. One matrimoniale and a double room. Expensive?! Maybe. Clean, great desayuno, AC available in all rooms. Parking on the street, just in front of the hotel.

name: Palapa Hostel
description:
Eco project in the heart of the town. 
Nice people come and go there. 
Ocean view from the main building. You can’t see the waves though… 
The hostel is still under construction. It can get noisy sometimes but that’s the spirit of Central America.

name: police stop
description: police stop, checked tailights (brake lights) seemed to be searching for a way to fine us, check inside camper, nothing they could find, on our way no problem

name: Don Jacks
description:
Awesome restaurant by American dude, who lives in Nica for a decade.
Great prices (see picture) and awesome quality with vegetarian options.

name: Badaboom Hostel
description:
very nice place with rooms and place for campers / RV's .  
Nice pool,  good restaurant,  clean showers and toilets.  
the owner Cedrik is a very friendly French guy who speaks perfectly English. 
5$ pP 
we were able to refill our water tank as well. 
Best place in this area !

name: Hospedaje Soma
description:
This hostel is beautiful and is run more like a hotel than hostel. There are private rooms with private bath as well as dorm type rooms. 
The grounds are lovely with lots of plants and flowers and there’s a pool and a restaurant. They have a lot of services here:
Rent motorbikes, ATV, bicycles etc and run an “honour bar” as well as have a full bar with options for smoothies and homemade ice cream as well. We booked a 1 hr massage for $20 USD and they came right to our room! It was awesome. 
The only downside to this place is that they have several roosters that start crowing very early in the morning 3 am, 4 am etc. there’s a dog on the property as well and it’s super sweet and well looked after but it barked here and there during the night as well. We are hoping tonight is not so noisy. We can generally tune out the roosters but it’s impossible when they are right outside your window even if you have earplugs. 
To end on a positive note… The desk staff speak English and the place is exceptionally clean. They also loaned me a yoga mat for some much needed morning exercise!
A great place - hoping to see rooster on the menu!!

name: Jakes on the Beach
description: Great hotel right on the ocean. Surfing & restaurants are right there. Gated secure parking for multiple vehicles. Friendly, very well travelled owner (Darren).  Big friendly dog (Jake) lives here. Darren is an adventure biker with lots of great trips under his belt.

name: Doña Neila
description:
Camping or Hammac place in the home garden. Just by the beach, view of the lake.
It's just 800m from the harbour, following 5he coastal path.
PERFECT FOR PEOPLE TRAVELING BY BIKE :)

name: Mirador de Cocibolca
description:
The beach access next door looked at the limit of what my RWD Astro could handle, so we asked in the restaurant if we could park up here. They welcomed our two vehicles, gave us WiFi and electricity, toilets and control over the lights, no hint of a fee. We had a snack and some drinks, plus breakfast the next morning at very reasonable prices (100 cordobas for gallo pinto, eggs, plantains, cheese and coffee, 30 for fresh juices). Lovely people, lovely breeze, lovely shade - I imagine also a lovely place to watch the sunrise if you're up early enough too!

We fit a van and truck-camper in, so one big rig would manage, anything more would seem rude. They had some slightly barky dogs and a couple of cats so I suspect taking pets might be an issue if you wanted to have them outdoors, don't know though.

name: Centro Social Tio Antonio
description: Amazing place where people with disabilities design and weave wonderful hammocks, chairs, bags and many other cool stuff. They also have a coffee place « Smile Coffee » where you can order coffee with sign language so the staff will understand you. Very playful and interesting place. They also sell coffee machine and mugs.

name: Cafetín/Hostal Rincón NICA
description:
$43/night for room with 3 beds, private bathroom, and A/C. The place doesn’t have its own parking but they asked the restaurant down the street, Asarte Restaurant and Grill (see other pin), to let us park our truck there for free and gave us 2 free drink tickets. Walking distance to town center. Bridget, the owner, is very friendly and is a salsa instructor and if you’re lucky you can take one of her free classes! Bridget only speaks Spanish but her daughter, also named Bridget, speaks both English and Spanish. 
@MoraVentures

name: Asarte Restaurante & Grill
description: Restaurant with secure private parking. They let us park here for 2 nights free with accommodation at Cafetin/Hostal Rincon NICA (see other pin). I believe there is an option to park here overnight for a fee if maybe you’re staying somewhere else. I did not inquire about camping but I think they would be open to it especially in the off season. Food here is pricey but good.

name: Uno - LSD (Low Sulfur Diesel)
description: Small Uno gas station that has low-sulfur diesel (LSD).

name: UNO - LSD (Low sulfur diesel)
description: Uno gas station right before entering Leon. Has low-sulfur diesel.

name: Hotel Don Augusto
description:
Cheap hotel 400 córdobas for a room with fan, normally they don't accept dogs but we told them is a trained dog and we also told them about our trip through center am , and they accepted him. Clean and cheap, not the nicest but they have private parking and we were there at night so it was good decision to stop before heading to Blue fields. 
The location in Google maps is incorrect, but is one block away. Friendly staff

name: Momotombo prior guarded gate
description:
On the road heading to Momotombo power plant. There is a minor path turning right with 2 or 3 places for a camper van under the trees. Ok for small/medium rig. A little maneuver is necessary but nothing too complicated.

There's nobody here and it's perfect to start the no-guide/no-permit Momotombo trail (on the other side of the road).

name: Hostal Rio Piedra
description: Wonderful Hostal ! They offer great rooms for less money. You can park the car in front on the street or in a parking lot. Didn’t use these option. The  Kitchen is amazing and super clean.

name: Potable water UNO Nagarote
description:
Water spigot at the UNO station. Asked the gas pump attendant who confirmed the water is potable. 
The fitting seems to be standard. I didn't use an adapter as I directly filled up my 5gal water container.
Enjoy !

name: Best Carwash/Oil change
description: They also do small mechanics, but we were here for the AutoLavado. The guys did a great job, very thorough! Washed inside outside and underneath the truck for: 200 Cordoba

name: Centro de Salud
description:
There are health centers (centros de salud) scattered throughout the island. We were in Playa Peru and my girlfriend hit her head on our countertop. Made a thick gash right below her eyebrow. 

There’s a “centro de salud” really close to Playa Peru (also a pin on iOverlander) but really bad and without supplies. The doctor told my girlfriend she didn’t need stitches and she definitely did. I recommend coming here if you don’t want to drive all the way to Moyo.

We came here and it’s a proper hospital structure. We were sent to the emergency room and she got 4 stitches very quickly. Really professional job. No check in or check out. No need for payment. Not sure how the medical system works here but we are super thankful!

Keep continuing straight past the hospital to park in a grassy dirt field. And if you don’t speak Spanish, get your favorite translation app out.

name: Bulk Dog Food Shop
description:
Bulk dog food, three different brands for for puppies and adults. Greenish painted building.

Cost ranges from 32-35 NIO per pound. Really nice people working!

name: Casa Ricardo Somoto
description:
Ricardo is a great guy, super friendly and really helpful. Showed us on his map where to go, even though we didn't want a guide he still helped us, even offered life jackets (didn't use, didn't need) and phone cases to us for free. Rooms are basic, but clean and you can see they tried to make them nice (paint, mosquito nets, a chair, small table thingy and a fan) Bathroom is shared with a water barrel for flushing but a running water shower (cold). We could park our motorbikes safely behind the locked gate right in front of our room. could also fit a car, or small van. but nothing too big, max 2,3 or so meters high (just a guess).

The family also offered us dinner (tamales, best ones since mexico) for just 50 Cordoba pP. breakfast, tipico, 50 cordobas each and a fried chicken dinner with rice (really good) for 100 each. Really good food.

rate for the room is 7 USD per person (2 nights double room with 2 people -> 1000 Cordoba).

Always happy to find these down to earth, basic and friendly family-run places for us low budget travelers still around.

name: Money exchangers
description: If you are crossing into Costa Rica, stop here to exchange money as the money exchangers are not allowed further up this point. You need dollars to pay for the exit fee.

name: Parque Los Robles
description:
Just street parking, but thought is was worth adding as there's not much on here for Managua. Decent spot on a wide road alongside a nice park, fairly quiet even on. a Saturday night once the sports folk had stopped being sporty on the court, nice and  shady under the trees and not much through traffic. And decent free WiFi, hurrah. 

No idea about facilities, though a couple of roads away is a Casa del Cafe which is open till 9 and pleasant to sit and tech in (their guard also invited me to overnight in the car park when I asked for recommendations of places to stay, which I did and had a lovely quiet night, so that could also be an option if you prefer a guarded place).

name: Potentiall Corrupt Police
description:
Checkpoint with two male cops. Older guy flagged us down to stop. As I slowed down, older guy got a little crazy with his hand  wanting us to seemingly slam on our brakes with cars behind us.

Pulled over. Younger cop asked for our documents. I gave him copies of the vehicle circulation permit, US registration, passports, and driver’s license. Always give copies! Asked for car insurance, and I gave him our Central America insurance purchased in Guatemala. 

Didn’t ask for originals. Older cop came over to confirm everything with the other. Seemed like he was training the younger one. Our car insurance was expired and they didn’t notice (I had a valid one as a PDF but hadn’t printed).

The younger cop had our copies in his hand as he began the start of his long lie. Rapid fire Spanish and no eye contact, telling us we were swerving (I think?) according to a certain Law XYZ. I switched to English and said I don’t understand what we were doing wrong. He got frustrated and said no English. I said ‘No entiendo el erro’ and he gave us back the papers, said we just need to drive safer, and we could go.

I’m not sure at what point he gave up in the scam or bribe attempt, but I feel like the older cop was training him for this. He seemed super uncomfortable. I didn’t even get a chance to show our dash cam footage!

name: Bomberos
description:
Friendly people. We could refill our tank without problems and really fast.

Gente súper amigable. Pudimos recargar el tanque sin problemas y bien rápido, buena presión de agua.

name: Parque El Dorado
description:
Another nice little urban park - no facilities that I saw, but it's quiet and shaded on the roadside under the trees, in an area that feels very safe. Spent a couple of nights here peacefully.

Free open slightly patchy wi-fi, and a nice little 'De La Finca' coffee shop on the corner.

name: Tapiceria Don Ernesto
description: I met Don Ernesto while shopping for fabric to repair my beaten seats in Managua, found he has a family-run tapiceria, and gave him a ride back to Granada. He did a great job on rebuilding and covering the seats for a ridiculously cheap fee. A few months later the side of one was coming a bit loose, and as I was back in Granada I returned and he took them out and touched them up - fast and professional, and I had to force more money on him for it! His number is +505 8652 8761

name: Aguas Agrias
description:
Nice balneario/bathing spot - a clearwater river that's been built up with rocks and cement along the shores. I came on a Sunday and it was rammed full of people, but being the antisocial tourist I am I headed upstream to the spring (right at the start in fact; turn right instead of left as soon as you get to the river) and had it virtually to myself, lovely and peaceful despite the music and splashing downstream.

Price for foreigners is 3 USD, plus 40 cordoba for the vehicle - 150 in total - marked spot is the carpark; you pay on entry when you turn off the dirt road to get here. 

I didn't stay overnight but asked at the gate and it's possible, they'd charge an extra 2 USD (not sure if that's per person or vehicle). No facilities. Apparently it's far quieter on a weekday. People were all leaving at around 4pm, and the howler monkeys were arriving for night shift at the river! Lovely spot after the heat and humidity of Granada.

name: OmetepeSpace
description:
Nice place to explore the island. Big flat green area full of trees to camp and park. Supercalm and quiet at night. Clean toilet with bucket shower.
Cesar a nice nicaraguan men help travellers, contact him first by whatssap +505 8886 0734. We even did a bike tour together in the island!
Muddy access from the road to Madera volcano. Walking access to the beach (2km).

name: Car Wash Express Panamericano
description: Car wash parking lot with a locked gate at night. Owner was very friendly and let us camp for free. After the long wait crossing the Nicaraguan border, this was the furthest we could take a bus before dark. Headed to Playa Santa María Del Mar this morning, only 45 mins from here.

name: Hotel Patio del Malinche
description: Super nice hotel in an awesome "colonial" building full of beatiful "patios" and a perfect swimming pool. Perfect rooms with a/c and great service. Friendly owners and super helpful staff. Great option to take a rest next to the center and the main topics in the beautiful city of Granada!

name: Mirror & Lights Theft
description: We stayed over at a friends in this neighborhood, and had our rear lights, side view mirror, and various other things stolen from our car over night. Police let us know mirrors and lights are commonly stolen to sell at the Managua Market.

name: Soccer field
description: We were driving on the small track and looking for a place to camp. It was pretty difficult since all the fields are barbed. We found this large sports field. Young people played here until sunset and then the night was very calm. In the morning there is a little passage because workers go to the finca right next door. The guard came to see us I did not understand everything but I do not think that our presence has disturbed, just surprised. To come here a 4x4 is warmly recommended (river crossing and step road).

name: Dirt road closed
description: There is a barrier blocking the track. The guard did not want to let us pass. To turn around it's complicated ...

name: Grassy field
description: Nice grassy field, this place is quiet and close to La Garnacha. The night is fresh. Don't miss to taste the cheese in La Garnacha.

name: On the way to San Cristóbal volcano
description: 2.5 km before the start of the hike to the San Cristóbal volcano and the Finca. This place is really quiet in the middle of the forest. It's dark because the vegetation is dense. Perfect place to sleep before attacking the ascent of the volcano especially if you do not want to pay the excessive price of the Finca campsite. A 4x4 is highly recommended to come here.

name: Super Clean
description:
Laundry service with the option of a full overnight service or to do it yourself. I chose the latter and was in and out in a little over an hour or so, cost me ¢455 for a decent sized load, with bedding etc, and softener. None of this pay by the item nonsense!

Open 8-5.45 Monday to Friday, 8-1.45 Saturday.

name: Malecon showers
description: Free open-air showers at the malecon/car park. There's a block of toilets here too but they were closed when I visited.

name: Hike to Volcán del Hoyo
description: Nice hike to the Hoyo volcano. Start of the hike is from the "Visitor Center" of Cerro Negro. Count about 12km for 750m of elevation. At the start of the hike you will have a beautiful view of Cerro Negro then you walk in the forest about 5km before arriving on the Volcan del Hoyo. Here is several curiosities, first the impressive sinkhole formed in the middle of the slope of the volcano, one could confuse it with a crater, then a hole in hell from which springs water vapor and sulfur dioxide. The crater is pretty and is also worth a visit. From there the view of the Momotombo volcano, Lake Managua, the Cerro Asososca and the Asososca lagoon is incredible! It is possible to camp on site if you wish.

name: Bosque del Reparto Los Angeles
description:
Nice little wooded park with lots of very shady parking along one side. Very wealthy-looking neighbourhood, cameras at the gates of the houses nearby, and there appears to be a guard at the end of the park 24/7. No facilities but very calm, had a good night

Plenty of space for big rigs. There would be lots of space for tents and hammocks too, but I suspect that might raise some eyebrows.

name: Seguro
description: immediately after you exit the roundabout on the left side of the road there are three cafe stalls and the lady who sells insurance is the third one to the right. RED SIGN CAFE CIENFUEGO IT IS NOT THE GREEN BUILDING ON THE OTHER PLACE MARKED.

name: Street parking
description:
If you have a smaller rig the Bomberos place is awesome! Those guys are very welcoming! Unfortunately my rig was too big to fit there, but they took me to large parking lot, but they didn’t allow me to stay in my vehicle at night. So I parked on the street, great safe spot! Next to a TV station, they even interviewed me!
People were so friendly, a guy brought me lunch!

name: Villanueva, Police Station
description: Stayed here at night before crossing border to Honduras. I did not wanted stay at the border. Very small and simple town.

name: Servicios veterinarios Aryam
description:
Mayra is a wonderful person and very knowledgeable vet! She can do the exportation papers for your dog!
Very recommended!

name: Hostal de Boca En Boca
description:
A theft occurred during our stay. The security of the items in the security lockers is non-existent. We put all of our things in the security locker and left to explore the city on foot. When we returned the only other person in our dorm room was frantically looking for his credit card. He thought he had misplaced it, we tried to help him look to no avail. 


We then got a notification from our bank saying that transactions were trying to be placed on OUR credit card in Nindiri (20 minute way from Granada). The card was the only one in our security locker when we left to explore and we never use it since it is our back up card. So the card never had an opportunity to be compromised otherwise. Having this happen at the exact same time as our only room mate lost his card is screaming theft. We still had the card but someone obviously got the information they needed off of it. 


Upon inspection of the locker I noticed that it looks secure but it is not actually bolted to the floor and the back Is open to the wall so all a person has to do to access it is lean it away from the wall like you would moving a bookshelf, and easily reach behind. The morning we left, I noticed a bag of mine was pulled between the wall and the security locker so someone had leaned the locker again and tried to get something once more. 


We contacted our bank, got the transaction canceled, and packed up and left. We did not talk to the staff about this, they were extremely unhelpful with our hostel room mate frantic requests for assistance and we feel this must be staff or regular contractors doing the theft since the hostel had very few guests, no one else in our room, and the security lockers are only compromised with intimate knowledge of their design. 

$10 pp for basic dorm.

name: Estadio Heroes y Martires de Septiembre
description: Large treed area next to the stadium - spent a couple of nights there and all was peaceful. Lots of trees for shade, plenty of space for big rigs. The first night I stayed there was a guard who recommended I park close to the building; I didn't see him on the second occasion. It's used as a cut-through so a few people walking past in the evening, and more in the morning, but was nice and peaceful at night. No facilities.

name: Estelí
description: Nice wide street, safe place to park and spend the night, close to downtown, next to Main Street!

name: Playa Santa Teresa
description: Several possibilities around here, we chose to go to the end of the path and park our 4x4 in the sand. The place is quiet and peaceful, the view of the Maderas volcano is magnificent. Behind the trees there is a beautiful view of the Concepción volcano. It is possible to swim in the lake. Locals pass by here by bike or on foot, they are very nice. The way to get here requires a high clearance vehicle and you need a 4x4 to park in the sand.

name: Fork to get to the crater lake
description:
I left my van here at the corner after chatting to a couple of locals who thought it wouldn't make it the final kilometre down the left fork to the house where you pay to access the lake. I think it would probably have been fine to about half way (RWD Chevy Astro), but would possibly have needed higher clearance beyond, there are some sections of loose sand and other bits quite rutted. I probably wouldn't try it after heavy rain, it looks like the kind of road that might become a river! A little leery of leaving the van here as it's pretty remote, but the local folk were friendly and reassuring and all was well.

Just over a km from here to Don Modesto's house, where he charged me a 30 cordoba entrance fee. Got the feeling he'd have liked to have sat and chatted for a while.. Two hour round trip from where I left the van, including 20 or 30 mins at the beautiful lagoon - worth the sweat for the swim! And you get a nice view of El Hoyo.

name: Plaza Mirador Sandino, free
description:
I was in the other spot at mirador El Crucero and a police officer told me that the place wasn't safe at night. He recommended this place which is safer as there is a guard all night. 

So it's the parking for the mirador Plaza Sandino. It has toilet for 10c and a little comedor. The view is pretty good from the belvedere especially when sunset. There is also a photocopies store across the street.

I asked the guard just to be sure that he's okay with me sleeping in my van and he was completely okay with that without any charge. Very friendly too.

As it is just next to the road, noise from cars and trucks is pretty loud but it gets quieter at night.

name: taller san miguel
description:
We pulled up in the morning & they were able to help us immediately with our axle problem. we had to wait five hours to get parts for our f150 but otherwise they were fast. the owner also speaks english. they did around 6hours of labor with the truck on lift the entire day cost 80USD without the parts
UPDATE: after checking their work we realized they put the wrong boot on & now every two day we have to go under the car to put zip ties to fix their mistake

name: checkpoint road
description: There was at least a checkpoint every mile on this road & we got stop at a few of them. a cop got really aggressive when he saw I was recording. we had to pay a bribe to another. this was really stressful. drive behind a bus or a truck so that they don’t see you so easily because it’s really bad & make sure to have a copy of your licence. one cop even tried to get a bribe without having my licence. the not speaking spanish act did not work as they pulled up google translate

name: Opposite the Super Express
description: Parked my van between 3 and 9pm just opposite the Super Express while I worked in El Desayunazo on the corner - came back to find my rear door and passenger window open, and my walking boots missing. Oddly I was woken by strange noises on the van in the early morning (parked up between La Coloni, a few blocks away, and the school), and when I walked round later found the same back door open. I think what happened was someone tried their key in my lock and found it worked - no damage to the door anywhere, and not the first time that's happened - but backed off when they saw me in bed, then later spotted the van here and tried their luck more successfully. I was even sitting in the restaurant with it in sight, grr! So, be warned, opportunistic thieves about!

name: Attempted break-in in front of the colegio
description:
Woken in the early hours by somebody trying - and succeeding - to open the back door of my van, presumably with a key as there was no damage and not much noise. They left, I assume when they saw me in bed and decided it was a bad idea (thankfully!) - but my van was burgled later that day a few blocks away (I've marked a separate pont for that); again they got in through the back doors. The exact spot was further up towards La Colonia. Shame as it's otherwise a decent spot, as long as you're not too wide, with shade in the morning from a taller building and pretty quiet. Cameras from the college too, but apparently no deterrent, and they wouldn't let me see the footage without a police report.

I'll be buying an internal lock shortly!

name: Auto electrician
description:
Good auto electrical place run by Winston, whose number was given to me be a mechanic recommended as the best in León by a long-term expat resident I met here. They came out promptly when I called at 5pm after I couldn't get my van started, got me moving, then sourced and replaced the solenoid for me the following day - ¢2250 all in. They don't sell parts directly but can source them for you locally. Winston's number is 8527 6006. Spanish only!

There's no sign of name to the taller, it's the entry just before the corner, look for lots of cars..

name: Street Parking - Montecarlo Hotel Casino
description:
On the sidewalk street in front of the Casino Hotel, very quiet and with permanent guard
----------
En la calle vereda de enfrente del Casino Hotel muy silencioso y con guardia permanente

name: Endurance Company
description: Here we got the insurance for Nicaragua. 30 days. 12$ US.

name: Parking at Community Park
description: The best spot we found in this city! It's a parking lot for the gated community park which is open from 10am to 9pm (toilets open probably only throughout the daytime). We asked the man at the gate about this place. It's safe, very favorite for locals. The park was full until 9pm, it was really nice just watching people enjoying the Friday evening there. We felt totally safe, no noise after opening hours, even the main lights turned off, street lights a little more far from our car were still on. Few cars stayed at the place overnight, we think RVs could be also fine.

name: Gaia forest cafe
description: The best coffee we found on our roadtrip over the all Central America! European prices, but totally worth it!

name: Check point
description: Check point they  check tip. drivers licence insurance and registration

name: Poza la Pila waterfall
description: A nice small waterfall to enjoy the hike from Finca Neblina del Bosque. This the gare where you enter the fall. It just a 50' walk to the falls from here

name: Poza la pila fall entrance from road
description:
This is where you get off the road and head towards the fall. The gate and fence are painted red. Just go downhill, cross the stream on the left, and then hike uphill to the  next gate. There is a charge to enter thru next gate to the fall.
If you are into Mahic Mushroom, look for them in late Oct/Nov

name: ATM
description: BAC ATM  $4 USD CHARGE TO WITHDRAW DOLLARS OR CORDOBAS.

name: ATM cajero
description: Bank and ATM RIGHT AFTER YOU you get out of the ferry gate.

name: Fresh market food vendors
description: Every Saturday from 10am to 3pm the community gets together in this beach to do a fresh market and lots of food vendor

name: power steering repair specialists
description: I had a problem with my 2008 4runner steering. The pump was okay but Pinion bearing had gone bad. Giovanni at Talleres Argo brought me here. This guy is a genious. He did an outstanding job repairing and rebuilding the parts.

name: Alternator rebuild.
description: This shop can build alternators and motors. They are really good.

name: Muffler shop
description: This guy can repair exhaust  pipe and mufflers. I had my 4runner repaired here. He can bend and twist the pipes too.

name: Open Field Off The Highway
description:
We were tired and wanted a rest and parked under a tree for shade. Hard packed dirt and gravel in a grassy area. Not too much trash by our estimation. 
A local came by and we chatted amicably as we explained our mobile home and our journey. He said he lived nearby and apparently reassured by our harmlessness he invited us to spend the night. 
There is some noise from the highway but the road is flat with no slowdowns so vehicles rush by relatively quietly. 
A strong claro signal was a bonus.

name: Telica volcano tours Trailhead
description:
1. This is the point where all the tour vehicles come and disembark to hike the trail. As you park tour vehicle, you will see there is an abandoned toilet that has two arrows pointing to the trail. That is where you need to go.
2. If you are driving, you can park the car here and stay overnight. It is pretty safe. I stayed a night here. No problems at all 
3. At 4:00 am and 4:00 pm, the tours stop for the sunrise and sunset hikes. If you are not sure, wait until they show up and follow them.
4. Make sure to take a flash light if you are doing a sunset hike. It gets dark, and the trail is difficult  to follow. 
4. Sunset hike leave tge trailhead by 4:00 pm. It will take 45 minutes to get to the crater. see the crater and then head across to see the setting sun at the north end. I did not come back to the crater, but you must stop again by the crater and see the red glow in the crater. 
5. The sunset views at the top are amazing.

name: Lisboutique Laundry
description: A pink and white house with a tiny black “Laundry service” sign is the spot. It’s the house right behind the Escobar monument. The owner is accommodating and helpful. We arrived at 9am Sunday and she immediately took our pile of reeking clothes and promised to return them later in the day. We decided to rest in the convenient parking area across from the house and asked her to call us when ready. Good service.

name: Telica Volcano right turn
description:
This is the spot where you make right turn to Telica volcano. There is a sign here too. If you do not have an AWD or 4x4 with high clearance,do not go. It's 6 mile to the place where the trail for the canyon starts. That is the point where most of the tour stop. This road ends 1 km past the point mentioned above.
Some photos added to help you decide if it's  worth driving past this point.

name: Tapihouse
description: Paid $35 for a single. Large rooms with cold AC, a big communal kitchen, small pool, and lots of parking. Breakfast included. Rooms need a coat of paint but otherwise comfortable. Quick 2 min walk to the beach. Lots of bars and restaurants nearby. Owner is from Minnesota, very friendly.

name: Brisas de Momotombo
description: The edge of the lake being full of mud, we took a small dirt road and spent 2 nights next to the house of Johnny and Esperanza who agreed to receive other travelers. They offered us a shower and toilet but we bathed in the lake. Good reception Claro, a little fresh wind, calm and peaceful place.

name: Street parking
description:
Street parking where handicap people watch the car for you. Nice next to the university and cathedral. Great for secure parking for the day. I paid the 40C for 5 hrs of parking. 
Late or early afternoon getting a spot may be an issue too.

name: casa del cafe
description: Great coffee and fast wifi. Cappuccino was $3.50. worth it though

name: Isla de Amor
description: Beautiful island to spend thr day. The ferry fom Puerto Allende leaves at 9:00, 11:00 and 1:00. The returns are at 3, 5 and 7 pm.There are 4 cabanas that you can also rent for half or full day. You cannot stay overnight right now. They have infinity pool and live music. A beautiful  place to spend the day.

name: Uno
description: Full service gas station, the first we’ve seen since Granada on the road to Costa Rica.

name: Santa Fe Bridge
description:
Coming to the border from Granada we arrived after dark and the border was closed at the south end of the bridge. The soldiers said we could fiend the night at the north end and we found an informal pull out. It is rainy season but close to the highway the ground was solid. There were some cabs and a collectivo also parked nearby actually on the bridge where they waited for late arrival pedestrians from the frontier. 
Reasonably quiet though there was some traffic in the night! Strong claro cell signal. 
There is a pulperia store under the bridge if you feel like shopping too. 
This stopping place seemed much quieter and private than the so called truck stop two kilometers into Nicaragua.

name: Korean B.B.Q Restaurant
description:
I came for a meal and stayed for free for five days. height restrictions 

A restaurant with a large parking lot and delicious Korean barbecue.
The charcoal barbecue was so good, it was the best I've ever had in Central America.
The Japanese food was also really good.
I ate my mail dinners here for 5 days

Best of all, the owner was very friendly.

We used the fast wifi, electricity, toilet, shower all for free.
We also felt safe as the gate and security guard kept us safe all night.

From here you are 40 minutes to Granada Lake and 20 minutes to Masaya Volcano.

name: Ometepe ferry ticket
description: is the office where you buy ticket for Ometepe Ferry. You have to pay $1 port fee before they will allow here. Make sure buy your ticket a day in advance or come here and if someone does not show up tgey may get you a ticket.

name: Beach camping by Palapa
description:
Stayed here for a night during the week. It was nice and quiet. A very secure place. Talk to a couple of locals who said it was all good here. I did not go fast this point. It really gets Sandy even though I have a 4x4. But if I get stuck solo I could get in big trouble. There are palapas next to this spot that you can utilize at your convenience.
May be this place gets busy. I am not sure. All good during week day.

name: ferry vehicle ticket
description: This is where you make your reservation or buy a ferry ticket for your car. Make sure you make a reservation in advance, or you will be put on the waiting list. It is Russoan roulete then.

name: Hostel-Camping Ojo de Agua
description:
Shower, kitchen, water, cabana, bedroom. 
.....
ducha
cocina
agua
cabaña
dormitorio
espacio para carpa y hamaca

name: Hostal Camping Ojo de Agua
description: All you need for campsite, also dorm and cabañas, kitchen and shower

name: Calalas Lodge and RV park (28 ft)
description:
Hotel with camping ground.

They offer large parking areas, connection to water and energy, as well as bathrooms and indoor and outdoor showers.

Each pitch is at least 40 m2 with power and water connection. (No AC use). Access  to bathrooms with shower. Wi-Fi Hotspot.

name: Uno drinking water faucet
description:
Free water with a standard faucet. Ask to the attendant before.
Pressure is low, but water is drinkable.
10 mn for our 60 liters tank.

name: Cascadas de la Luna
description: We spend 2 night next to the river just the waterfalls started. different activities to do. rappelling 250c canopy 150c solo or 200c w/ guide. Hiking to the cave and poza (2 hrs round trip) 150 c w/guide. Walk to the waterfalls solo is free with guide 50c Parking over night is free just if you want to give a tip to the overnight security is opcional (50c or 100c ) Pablo was ours guide, he left the bathroom open at night for us. locals are very friendly. it's a restaurant- bar (mapache) it's a little laud but close early. we spent relaxed nights.

name: Playa Majagual
description:
We stood on the beach restaurant for the night for free. There are a cold outside shower and restrooms.
We asked the restaurant and they told us it was ok if we were eating or drinking something. 
A bit pricy for Nicaragua (8$ for à meal) but very good ! 
Lovely and quiet  place on the beach (you can swim , not too big waves, no currents)

name: Community Park and Museum
description: We parked one night at this park. we asked the locals and they told us it is safe. there was some traffic until midnight. “FREE WIFI” and there is a water spigot. asked the secure guard and we filled our jug. hose didn’t reach.

name: Mniam restaurant polaco
description:
The Mniam is an exceptional address where you will be welcomed by an extremely kind Polish couple.  You can taste local or Polish cuisine (see the menu in the photo), drink beers, tasty cocktails or even incredible iced coffees, homemade smoothies, all in a magnificent setting with good music.  There's even a room to rent with a double bed, for $30 (or $35 with breakfast).  The free wifi is very fast.

Le Mniam est une adresse exceptionnelle où vous serez reçus par un couple polonais extrêmement gentil. Vous pourrez déguster de la cuisine locale ou polonaise (voir la carte en photo), boire des bières, des cocktails savoureux ou encore des cafés glacés incroyables, des smoothies maison, le tout dans un cadre magnifique avec de la bonne musique. Il y a même une chambre à louer avec un lit 2 places, pour 30 USD (ou 35 USD avec le petit-déjeuner). Le wifi gratuit est très rapide.

El Mniam es un establecimiento excepcional donde le recibirá una pareja polaca muy amable.  Podrás degustar cocina local o polaca (ver menú en la foto), tomar cervezas, sabrosos cócteles o incluso increíbles cafés helados, batidos caseros, todo en un entorno magnífico y con buena música.  Incluso hay una habitación para alquilar con cama doble, por $30 (o $35 con desayuno).  El wifi gratuito es muy rápido.
